Name: Munros
Description: Scottish hills at least 3,000ft in height regarded by the SMC as distinct and separate mountains, based on a list originally published in 1891.

Name: Munro tops
Description: Subsidiary summits of the Munros (Scottish hills at least 3,000ft in height regarded by the SMC as distinct and separate mountains).

Name: Corbetts
Description: Scottish hills between 2,500 and 2,999ft high with a drop of at least 500ft (152.4m) on all sides.

Name: Corbett tops
Description: Subsidiary summits of the Corbetts (Scottish hills between 2,500 and 2999ft high with a drop of at least 500ft (152.4m) on all sides).

Name: Grahams
Description: Scottish hills at least 600m high and below 762m (2,500ft) with a drop of at least 150m on all sides.

Name: Graham tops
Description: Subsidiary summits of the Grahams (Scottish hills at least 600m high and below 762m (2,500ft) with a drop of at least 150m on all sides).

Name: Donalds
Description: Hills in the Scottish Lowlands at least 2,000ft high, over 100ft (30.5m) in prominence, and which also have "sufficient topographical merit".

Name: Donald tops
Description: Hills in the Scottish Lowlands of at least 2,000ft (610m) in height with a drop of at least 50ft (15m) between each elevation and any higher elevation. Further, elevations separated from higher elevations by a drop of less than 100ft (30m) are required to have "sufficient topographical merit"

Name: Murdos
Description: Scottish hills at least 3,000ft in height with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Donald Deweys
Description: Hills in the Scottish Lowlands at least 500m high and below 609.6m with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Highland Fives
Description: Hills in the Scottish Highlands and Islands at least 500m high and below 600m with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Marilyns
Description: Hill of any height with a prominence or drop of 150m (nearly 500ft) or more on all sides.

Name: Twin Marilyns
Description: A summit of equal height to another Marilyn where the drop between the two is less than 150m and at least 30m.

Name: HuMPs
Description: Hills of any height with a drop of 100m or more on all sides. The name HuMP stands for HUndred Metre Prominence.

Name: Twin HuMPs
Description: A summit of equal height to another HuMP where the drop between the two summits is at least 30m but less than 100m.

Name: TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Simms
Description: Hills in England, Wales or Scotland over 600m high with a drop of at least 30m all round.

Name: Dodds
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man and Ireland between 500m and 599.9m high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Furths
Description: English, Welsh and Irish summits equivalent to the Munros (Scottish hills at least 3,000ft in height regarded by the SMC as distinct and separate mountains).

Name: Hewitts
Description: Hills in England, Wales and Ireland at least 2,000ft high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Nuttalls
Description: Hills in England and Wales at least 2,000ft high with a drop of at least 15m on all sides, as published in The Mountains of England and Wales.

Name: Deweys
Description: Hills in England, Wales and the Isle of Man at least 500m high and below 609.6m with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: 400m to 499m TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: 300m to 399m TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: 200m to 299m TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: 100m to 199m TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: 0m to 99m TuMPs
Description: Hills in Scotland, England, Wales, the Isle of Man or Channel Islands which is separated from adjacent tops by a height difference of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Wainwrights
Description: The 214 hills listed in volumes 1-7 of Wainwright's A Pictorial Guide to the Lakeland Fells.

Name: Wainwright outlying fells
Description: Hills listed in The Outlying Fells of Lakeland.

Name: Birketts
Description: Lake District hills over 1,000ft listed in Bill Birkett's Complete Lakeland Fells.

Name: Ethels
Description: Listing of 95 summits in the Peak District.

Name: High hills of Britain
Description: Ground at least 838m above sea level on the mainland and above 770m on islands.

Name: Synges
Description: Lake District hills over 1,000ft published in Tim Synges' The Lakeland Summits.

Name: Fellrangers
Description: Lake District hills included in Mark Richards' Fellranger walking series.

Name: County tops (historic pre-1974)
Description: The highest point within (or sometimes on) the boundary of each county.

Name: Twin county tops (historic pre-1974)
Description: A top of equal height to the highest point within the boundary of each county.

Name: County tops (current county or unitary authority)
NameSingular: County top (current county or unitary authority)
Description: The highest point within (or sometimes on) the boundary of each county.

Name: Twin county tops (current county or unitary authority)
NameSingular: Twin county top (current county or unitary authority)
Description: A top of equal height to the highest point within the boundary of each county.

Name: County tops (administrative 1974 to mid-1990s)
Description: The highest point within (or sometimes on) the boundary of each county.

Name: Twin county tops (administrative 1974 to mid-1990s)
Description: A top of equal height to the highest point within the boundary of each county.

Name: County tops (current London boroughs)
Description: The highest point within (or sometimes on) the boundary of each county.

Name: Twin county tops (current London boroughs)
Description: A top of equal height to the highest point within the boundary of each county.

Name: Significant islands of Britain
Description: Naturally occurring land, which at MHWS is shown on available OS mapping to be completely surrounded by water, with either an area of at least 30 hectares within the MHWS contour line or an "easily accessed" summit prominence of at least 30m above MSL, all man-made links and structures being discounted.

Name: Sub-Marilyns
Description: Hills not meeting the prominence criterion for Marilyns by 10m or less.

Name: Sub-HuMPs
Description: Hills not meeting the prominence criterion for HuMPs by 10m or less.

Name: Sub-Simms
Description: Hills not meeting the prominence criterion for Simms by 10m or less.

Name: Sub-Dodds
Description: Hills not meeting the prominence criterion for Dodds by 10m or less.

Name: Sub 400m to 499m TuMPs
Description: Hills not meeting the prominence criterion for 400m to 499m TuMPs by 10m or less.

Name: Buxton & Lewis
Description: Hills listed by Buxton & Lewis (1986).

Name: Bridges
Description: Hills listed by Bridge (1973).

Name: Yeamans
Description: Scottish hills with a drop of 100m, or, failing that, at least 5km (walking distance) from any higher point.

Name: Clems
Description: Hills in England, Wales and the Isle of Man with a drop of 100m, or, failing that, at least 5km (walking distance) from any higher point.

Name: Trail 100s
Description: List of 100 hills published in Trail magazine.

Name: Deleted Munro tops
Description: Deleted Munro top

Name: Deleted Corbetts
Description: Deleted Corbett

Name: Deleted Grahams
Description: Deleted Graham

Name: Deleted Nuttalls
Description: Deleted Nuttall

Name: Deleted Donald tops
Description: Deleted Donald top

Name: Dillons
Description: Hills in Ireland at least 2,000ft high published in The Mountains of Ireland.

Name: Vandeleur-Lynams
Description: Hills in Ireland at least 600m high with a drop of at least 15m on all sides.

Name: Arderins
Description: Hills in Ireland at least 500m high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Carns
Description: Hills in Ireland between 400m and 499.9m high with a drop of at least 30m on all sides.

Name: Binnions
Description: Hills in Ireland with height below 400m and a drop of at least 100m on all sides.

Name: Other lists
Description: Other list

Name: Unclassifieds
Description: Unclassified
